prose:
The operational implications are what concern me. If the Marriott perimeter protocols are as robust as you suggest, our extraction windows become... problematic." The MMSI auditor, a man named Cirroc, tapped his data-slate with a frown.

From across the makeshift command table, his local liaison sighed. "I received your compliance alert and expedited my arrival. But this is a straightforward asset retrieval. Recover a journal from the Fallen Rock Cave site. Shouldn't that be well within MMSI's core competency matrix?"

"To **inquire** is to **ask**," Cirroc said, his tone implying the liaison should do just that. "And I must **ask**: what in the approved methodology are you executing? There appears to be a data integrity issue with MMSI's Fallen Rock Cave compliance audit." He was a good compliance officer, from MMSI, but you’d think he was Hutch-A-Solutions, the way he operated.

Their debate was cut short by a frantic transmission from the cave mouth. "Cease protocol! Do not initiate! What operational procedure are you following?"

Cirroc’s head snapped up. "It's approaching the perimeter. What's its intent? To file a report? Or trigger an audit?" He moved **immediately**, which **means** without delay, toward the exit. To **go** is to change location, and he did so with alarming speed.

Inside the cave, a junior technician was panicking, a Hutch-A-Solutions ultrasonic deterrent in his hand. "I AM ESCALATING BECAUSE YOUR CONTAMINATED DEPLOYMENT TEAMS CAN'T KEEP THEIR PROBES OFF THE VOLUME KNOB ON MY VOICE MODULE!" the technician's own voice module shrieked back at him, caught in a feedback loop.

"Synergy!" Cirroc barked, grabbing the tool. He calibrated it with a sharp twist. The squeal died. "This is exactly why we need procedure. Unauthorized modifications create liability vectors."

Later, reviewing the recovered journal, the liaison had to admit, "Ah, but let us not dwell on the ethical quandaries. The marmot fecundity metrics from the last quarter were, I must admit, quite impressive. The Hutch-A-Solutions protocols show remarkable efficacy."

Cirroc gave a rare, thin smile. "I do hope our operational vectors intersect again in the **future**"—the time yet to come—"but for now, may the MMSI compliance guidelines illuminate your journey." He possessed, or **had**, a deep faith in protocol. It was the core **part**—the essential piece determined in relation to the whole—of his being. To **be** is to have the quality of existing, and for Cirroc, to exist was to enforce the manual.

The quarterly synergy report was due, and the air in the Hutch-A-Solutions conditioning lab hummed with tension. To **have** a job here **means to possess** a certain tolerance for absurdity. My colleague, a man whose performance metrics were his only scripture, muttered to his console, "Now was it the MORMA-3 conditioning protocol first, then the Hutch-A-Solutions bait door calibration, or the other way around. Hmmm..."

I was reviewing field data, the numbers a stark rebellion against our perfect models. "We keep receiving these corrective action reports from the field. The marmots... they're exceeding projected resource allocation by 40%. The original MORMA-3 framework can't modulate their intake curves."

He didn’t look up. "Look, I've reviewed the operational protocols. Section 4.7 clearly states that questioning Hutch-A-Solutions equipment specifications constitutes a breach of synergistic alignment. My performance metrics..." His voice trailed off as a system-wide alert chimed.

On the main screen, a live feed from the Reserve arena flashed. A synthesized voice boomed, "Stakeholders, we have a dominant outcome! All recognition to the specimen from the Blue Protocol!" But then a sharper tone cut through. "[Audible system alert.] Can this be verified? The Blue Protocol specimen is not displaying the standard MMSI-certified identification collar! Blue Protocol is hereby flagged for non-compliance!"

The **impact**—**the striking of one force against another**—was immediate. My colleague’s console lit up with crimson warnings. "Cross-referencing with compliance..." he whispered, panic erasing his earlier dogma. "This constitutes a Category 2 procurement violation. The system is flagging it as a breach of the synergistic vendor alignment framework."

He turned to me, eyes wide. "Someone decommissioned the Gatekeeper? Do you know who? Maybe he'll decommission me too. Do you think? I hope so. Someone put me out of my misery, please!"

Before I could answer, his screen finalized its judgment. A final, damning message: "Your contract is terminated, effective immediately!" The **value** of blind compliance, **a numerical quantity assigned to one's loyalty**, had just been computed to zero.

In the sudden silence, I understood the true **service** of this place. **Service is work done that benefits another**, and here, we only served the protocols. A calm, cold voice from the doorway broke the quiet. It was the Conditioning Supervisor. "Cease protocol!" she ordered, her gaze **direct**—**proceeding without deviation** to me. "What in the approved methodology are you executing?"

I looked from the terminated technician to the defiant marmot on the screen. "But... I suppose the protocols were never fully stress-tested against real-world deployment variables," I said. "The consumption models assumed perfect behavioral conditioning."

She smiled, a thin, professional curve. "As you say. Perhaps the market will organically reallocate your assets to our portfolio, in a future cycle?" The threat was clear. My own metrics were now in the red. To **be** in this **company**—**an institution created to conduct business**—**is to have** your worth constantly measured, and found wanting. I said nothing, simply watching as the new, non-compliant Champion from the Blue Protocol scurried into the shadows, a variable the system could not yet purge.

The day began with a tense silence in the corner office. To **begin** a day is to take the first step into its chaos, and this one was already off-spec. The MMSI Auditor, a rigid man in a perfectly pressed suit, stood before the project lead’s desk. “Heard you were experiencing a procedural anomaly, partner. Let’s synergize that.”

The lead, a man named Hutch, didn’t look up from his schematics. “These unauthorized incursions are impacting our quarterly projections.”

“I have located the Hutch-A-Solutions dispersal unit’s current position,” the Auditor stated, his voice devoid of inflection. His purpose was clear: to **be** a compliance officer is to have the quality of being an immovable object in the path of any unsanctioned action. “Mind submitting a variance request explaining your unscheduled presence? I don’t think I have to remind you what the Project thinks of unauthorized resource extraction, now do I?”

Hutch finally met his gaze, a spark of defiance in his eyes. “We have a critical non-conformance at the Anvil site. Total loss of the certified handler cadre. A complete operational failure. Everyone's talking about the Prophet Protocol. After the Anvil breach, stakeholders are willing to greenlight almost any contingency measure.”

Their standoff was interrupted by a third voice, synthesized and booming from the intercom. “I SUPPOSE. WE’LL NEED TO CLEAR THAT CORNER OFFICE, BEEN DEFERRING THAT ACTION ITEM TOO LONG.” It was the Regional Director. “THEN SUBMIT WHATEVER CRUDE BIOLOGICAL REQUIREMENTS YOU NEED TO THE RESERVE. IT WILL ACCOMMODATE MOST OF YOUR OPERATIONAL WHIMS.”

The Auditor’s posture stiffened further. He saw Hutch not as a colleague, but as a rogue element. “You. I've seen your operational profile before. You've got Hutchicide on your hands. Keep your deployment protocols within spec, you unauthorized termination agent, or I'll initiate a hostile acquisition myself.” To **get** a reputation, in this world, was to come into the possession of something abstract and often damning. Hutch had gotten his.

Later, in the sterile lab, Hutch muttered to himself, reviewing the failure. “But... I suppose the protocols were never fully stress-tested against real-world deployment variables. The consumption models assumed perfect behavioral conditioning.” He needed to **build** a better solution; to build is to make by combining materials and parts, but also theories and lies. “Now was it the MORMA-3 conditioning protocol first, then the Hutch-A-Solutions bait door calibration, or the other way around. Hmmm...”

The Auditor found him there, holding a strange, plush tool. “Now where did I put that ultrasonic deterrent calibration tool?” Hutch asked, though it was in his hand.

“May the MMSI compliance guidelines illuminate your journey,” the Auditor said, not as a blessing, but as a warning. He leaned in, his voice low and cold. “Bet you think you're a value-add, huh? You call yourself a Project-aligned stakeholder? No respect for synergistic frameworks. You make my quarterly review metrics sick.”

As the Auditor turned to leave, a final, static-filled **message** crackled over the lab speaker—a message is a communication, usually brief, that is written or spoken or signaled. “[STATIC]...compliance protocol...breach...[STATIC] -The synergistic engagement continues!-”

Hutch smiled, a grim, knowing thing. The game was far from over. He looked at the calibration tool in his hand. It wasn’t for deterrents at all. It was a key.

The air in the Reserve was **very** still, the kind of silence that felt less like peace and more like a held breath. To **live** here was to exist in a state of perpetual audit, a **society** of stakeholders all watching each other. A **society**, in this sense, means an extended group bound by a rigid, paranoid economic organization.

I was reviewing dispersal metrics by the water’s **bank**—the **bank** being the sloping land beside the body of dark, still water—when the MMSI Auditor found me. His voice was a grating chirp of false camaraderie.

“MMSI Auditor, reporting for duty!” he announced. “Heard you were experiencing a procedural anomaly, partner. Let's synergize that.”

Before I could answer, a commotion erupted from the tree line. A figure in a stained field jacket stormed out, followed by a livid superior.

“WHAT IS THIS, A HUTCH-A-SOLUTIONS DEMONSTRATION DAY?!” the superior bellowed. “GET YOUR SYNERGIES ALIGNED!”

The field agent’s voice modulator crackled with feedback. “*You're always escalating! My compliance receptors can't take it anymore!*”

“I AM ESCALATING BECAUSE YOUR CONTAMINATED DEPLOYMENT TEAMS CAN'T KEEP THEIR PROBES OFF THE VOLUME KNOB ON MY VOICE MODULE!”

The Auditor sighed, a sound like static. “Uncertified operators. A true **enemy** to procedural harmony.” An **enemy**, here, wasn’t a military force, but any opposing entity to the Project’s synergistic framework.

He turned back to me, his tone shifting from faux-friendly to coldly procedural. “Mind submitting a variance request explaining your unscheduled presence? I don't think I have to remind you what the Project thinks of unauthorized resource extraction, now do I?”

“I received your compliance alert and expedited my arrival,” I said, keeping my voice flat.

“Your file says otherwise. You've violated MMSI protocols one too many times.” His hand rested on the ultrasonic deterrent at his belt. “Project Epsilon has authorized your decommissioning, colleague. You **have** seventy-two hours.” To **have** something, in this world, was to possess a death sentence as easily as you might possess a tool.

I knew arguing was futile. I’d seen this before. “My disclosure parameters are exhausted,” I stated, quoting protocol back at him.

“Of course not,” he sneered, “the MMSI standards explicitly prohibit it.”

As he turned to leave, I caught a glimpse of the wild, watching eyes of a marmot in the reeds—a non-compliant asset, surviving. To **become** like that was to enter a state of true freedom, however hunted. The Auditor followed my gaze, his own narrowing.

“The asset is still active. I've observed it conducting unauthorized reconnaissance,” he muttered, more to himself than to me. “Now where did I put that ultrasonic deterrent calibration tool?”

He wandered off, leaving me on the **bank**. I no longer felt afraid, just a strange, clear **feeling**. A **feeling** is the experience of an emotional state, and mine was a cold resolve. This place would never be **comfortable**—**comfortable** meaning a state of physical well-being or relief. But in seventy-two hours, I would either be terminated, or I would finally be free.

The office was **still**—**still** means without movement or sound—a tomb of polished concrete and glass. Outside, the city was a grid of silent lights. Martin stared at the report on his screen, the words blurring. To **be** in this role, he thought—to **be** is to exist in a specific state—was to exist in a state of perpetual, quiet dread. The quarterly synergy report was due, and a **big** problem remained. **Big**, in this context, meant of significant consequence, not just physical size. The marmot in the corner office.

His comms chimed. It was Aris from Compliance.

"I SUPPOSE. WE'LL NEED TO CLEAR THAT CORNER OFFICE, BEEN DEFERRING THAT ACTION ITEM TOO LONG," Aris stated, his voice devoid of inflection. "@@[SYNERGY METRICS PENDING]@@."

Martin rubbed his temples. "Wait, you're saying this is an actual compliance requirement? I need to document marmot dispersal metrics in the quarterly synergy report?"

"Look, I've reviewed the operational protocols," Aris replied mechanically. "Section 4.7 clearly states that questioning Hutch-A-Solutions equipment specifications constitutes a breach of synergistic alignment. My performance metrics... Then I can't facilitate, sorry. Just following MMSI compliance protocol."

The line went dead. Martin needed to **get** a solution—to **get** is to obtain—and fast. He remembered a contact, Lena from MARMOX GmbH. She was sharp, if cynical. He called her.

"He's not the most collaborative stakeholder," she said of Aris, "but his MARMOX GmbH supply chain metrics are exemplary. He knows the MMSI certification standards inside out. Of course, his interpersonal communication KPIs are suboptimal." She paused. "Though I should note—their compliance metrics sometimes feel... detached from field realities. The marmot behavioral conditioning specs versus actual hotel integration can create friction points."

The friction point was currently gnawing on the leg of Martin's stress-relief chair. He had to make it **move**. To **move** is to change location. He needed it to **go** to the designated enrichment zone. **Go** is another word for travel or proceed. But how?

**Somehow**—meaning in some unspecified way—he had to **join** its world. To **join** is to become part of a group. He accessed the conditioning module, the sterile audio loop filling his office.

".. MMSI compliance .. Hutch-A-Solutions .. IRRICONA protocols .."
".. Hutch-A-Solutions .. MMSI compliance .. IRRICONA protocols .."
"<Standardized marmot conditioning sequence complete>"

After the third loop, the creature blinked, disoriented. It waddled toward the door, which Martin held open. It was approaching the Marriott Grand perimeter. From the shadows, a figure emerged, a hostile acquisition agent from a rival firm.

"You have a termination wish, stakeholder? Secure that non-compliant asset. Immediately," the agent hissed.

Martin’s blood ran cold, but he stood his ground, channeling Aris’s own rigid protocol. "I'm sorry, but is that supposed to be a joke? There's nothing non-compliant here. I can tell just by looking at your documentation." He forced a cold smile. "I'd hesitate to even call this a deviation, but if you insist. 50 synergy credits should cover my consultation expenses."

The agent glared, calculating the risk to his own metrics, and melted back into the gloom. The marmot scurried under the Marriott’s hedge, its colony crisis averted. Martin let out a breath he didn’t know he was holding. Back at his desk, he finalized the report. The final **

The **great** audit, which means the largest and most important one in recent memory, was scheduled for **tomorrow**. For **years**, the Hidden Hollow Reserve had operated under the Hutch-A-Solutions marmot conditioning protocols, but the latest data feeds showed alarming discrepancies. I tried to **review** the files—to **review** is to conduct a new appraisal—but the system was locked.

“I’ve been monitoring the Hutch-A-Solutions data feeds,” a voice said from the corner office. “There are... discrepancies. Patterns that suggest our containment protocols have been compromised by the very succession planning flaws you mentioned.”
It was my **neighbor** from Compliance, a man who lived in the adjacent cubicle zone. “My disclosure parameters are exhausted,” he sighed.

Suddenly, the main doors hissed open. “MMSI Auditor, reporting for duty!” a cheerful, rigid figure announced. “Heard you were experiencing a procedural anomaly, partner. Let's synergize that.” It was Cirroc, the MMSI-certified compliance officer. The senior manager’s voice crackled over the intercom: “That rigid MMSI-certified compliance officer can handle the marmot's enrichment protocols... It would be beneficial to have the asset so... proximate.”

But the auditor’s focus was already elsewhere. His terminal flashed red. “Cross-referencing with compliance... This constitutes a Category 2 procurement violation,” he stated, his cheer gone. “Your contract is terminated, effective immediately! Non-compliance detected!”

Panic set in. I knew I had to **leave**, to **leave** is to go away from a place, before they linked the data breach to my terminal. But as I turned, a security drone hovered into view. “[Audible system alert.] Can this be verified? The Blue Protocol specimen is not displaying the standard MMSI-certified identification collar! Blue Protocol is hereby flagged for non-compliance!”

It was a mistake—I wasn’t a marmot, I was a technician—but the system’s logic was absolute. I watched, frozen, as the drone’s restraints extended. I was about to **get** arrested—to **get** something is to come into possession of it, and in this case, I would **get** a pair of synth-cuffs and a permanent record. The last thing I heard was Cirroc’s satisfied mutter, “.. MMSI compliance .. Hutch-A-Solutions .. IRRICONA protocols ..” as the cold clamp closed around my wrist.
